lines.text: (d) Apparent Purity: If apparent purity is desired on hot cake alone,
follow the method given under "12.
Composite Saccharate Cake".
Special Methods
Sugar-Soluble CaO:
Weigh out 10 grams, reduce to a milk with water,
and rinse into a 100 ml flask.
Add 20 grams of granulated sugar and dissolve by
the addition of water, or add the same amount of sugar in the form of a freshly pre-
pared sugar solution, e. g. 50 ml of a solution containing 400 grams of sugar per
liter, or 25 ml of a solution made by dissolving 500 grams of sugar in 300 grams of
water (a solution of approximately 620 Brix). Fill to the mark with water, stopper
the flask, shake gently for two or three minutes until most of the saccharate goes
into solution, then allow to stand 30 minutes, shaking every 5 to 10 minutes during
the period of standing.
Filter, rejecting the first runnings, and titrate 50 ml
of the filtrate with standard Steffen nitric acid (1 ml= .05 gram Ca0), using phenol-
phthalein as indicator.
The number of milliliters of acid required represents the
percentage of Cao.
(f) co2:
This determination may be made to establish the loss of eff-
iciency of hot saccharate precipitation due to the presence of CO2 in the vapor used
for heating.
Use the bomb method for soil described in chapter 22, section 4 (p. 2206).
COMPOSITE SACCHARATE CAKE
Determine every 24 hours:
Apparent purity
True purity
Raffinose (% on dry substance )
N value (% on dry substance)
Preparation of sample
After mixing individually the samples of cold and hot saccharate cake described
in sections 8 and 9, prepare by weight a composite of suitable amount in the same pro-
portion by weight as the relative amounts of cold and hot saccharate produced according
to the laboratory records.
Analysis
(a) Apparent purity: The following special apparatus is needed: a carbonator
with steam and carbon dioxide gas connections and an evaporator heated by steam, both so
constructed as to obviate any possibility of burning the juice. Suitable apparatus is
described in the Chemical Bulletin, p. 419, and in drawings SS-195-19, SS-196-19, and
Mix a suitable amount of the cake with water of low solids content until a homo-
geneous mixture is obtained; the amount of water used should be such that the filtrate
after subsequent carbonation will have a density of 5 to 6 degrees Brix.
Transfer to
the laboratory carbonator, heat to 80-85, and carbonate at this temperature to faint
alkalinity with phenolphthalein. Do not carbonate to neutrality or acidity.
When the
carbonation is finished, heat to boiling, and filter. Concentrate sufficient of the
filtrate to 20-23 Brix in the laboratory evaporator, being careful not to carry the
evaporation beyond this point on account of the danger of burning the juice.
Draw off
the liquid into a copper can and carbonate again in a laboratory hot water bath to faint
alkalinity. Filter under vacuum through a Buchner funnel.
Cool the filtrate in a
Section 4.
cylinder and determine the apparent purity as described in the General Methods, Chapter 1,
The Great Western Sugar Company
Methods of Analysis
Chemical Department
Steffen Process Control
